tasks.title: Create Language Skill Directory Structure and Base Templates
tasks.description: Set up the foundational directory structure for all 5 language skills (Go, Python, Java, Kotlin, TypeScript) with consistent file templates and framework extension support
tasks.details:
Create the base directory structure under .claude/skills/ for each language skill following the naming convention lang-<language>. Each skill directory must contain: SKILL.md (entry point with navigation), style.md, testing.md, tooling.md, patterns.md, and frameworks/ subdirectory with README.md and .gitkeep. Use a consistent markdown template structure across all files. The SKILL.md template should include frontmatter with name and description fields, followed by sections for overview, quick reference, topic links, and usage scenarios. Topic files should have placeholder sections ready for content population. The frameworks/README.md should provide clear instructions for adding framework-specific guides with a template structure example.

Reference Documentation:
- Design: /docs/wip/language-specific-skills/design.md
- Implementation Plan: /docs/wip/language-specific-skills/implementation.md (Phase 1, Tasks 1.1-1.4)
tasks.testStrategy: Verify all 5 language skill directories exist with correct structure using filesystem assertions. Validate that each SKILL.md contains proper frontmatter and required sections. Ensure all markdown files have valid syntax and working relative links between files. Test that frameworks/ directories contain both README.md and .gitkeep files. Use a schema validator to ensure consistent structure across all language skills.

tasks.title: Implement Language-Specific Content for All Skills
tasks.description: Research and write comprehensive, practical content for each language skill covering style conventions, testing strategies, tooling ecosystem, and design patterns
tasks.details:
For each language, create detailed content adhering to size requirements (50-100 lines for SKILL.md, 150-300 lines for topic files). Go content should cover: exported naming, table-driven tests, go mod/work, error wrapping, goroutines. Python should include: PEP 8, type hints, pytest vs unittest, pip/poetry/uv comparisons, decorators, async patterns. Java needs: modern features (records/sealed), JUnit 5, Maven/Gradle, builder pattern, Optional usage. Kotlin requires: null safety, Kotest/MockK, coroutines, sealed classes, DSLs. TypeScript must have: type vs interface, Jest/Vitest, tsconfig best practices, utility types, discriminated unions. Focus on actionable insights unique to each language, avoiding generic programming concepts. Include current tool versions and modern practices (2024 standards).

Reference Documentation:
- Design: /docs/wip/language-specific-skills/design.md (see "Content Guidelines" and "Language Coverage" sections)
- Implementation Plan: /docs/wip/language-specific-skills/implementation.md (Phase 2, Tasks 2.1-2.5)
tasks.testStrategy: Content review checklist: verify each topic file meets line count requirements (150-300 lines), check for technical accuracy against official documentation, validate that examples use current syntax and libraries, ensure no framework-specific content in core files, test that all internal markdown links resolve correctly. Use automated readability scoring to ensure content is clear and actionable.
